translated: The Elder Tipadumiya’s Birth Story
“The Victor named Padumuttara,
who had gone beyond all things,
tamed, surrounded by the tamed,
left the city at that time.
In the city of Haṁsavati,
I was a garland maker then;
I took the three best lotus flowers
that were there.
I saw the dust-free Buddha
on the road between the two cities;

analyzed: saha disvāna sambuddha  evam cintesaham tadā
translated: Having seen the Sambuddha,🔽I thought this at that time:
‘What is the use of these flowers
that have been brought for the King?
I could get a village or a field or
a thousand (coins) for them.
The hero who tames the untamed,
who brings happiness to all beings,
having worshipped the Lord of the World,
I could get the treasure of immortality.’
Having thought thus,
I gladdened my own mind;
Taking the three red (flowers),
I threw them up into the air.
As soon as I threw them up,
they spread out in the sky;
They stood on his head there,
with their stalks above and their faces below.
Whatever humans saw,
they all broke out in applause;
The gods in the sky
also broke out in applause.
A wonder has arisen in the world,
through the power of the Buddha, the best;
We will all listen to the Dhamma,
through the power of the flowers.
Padumuttara, the knower of the world,🔽the receiver of offerings,

translated: while standing on the road,

‘The young brahmin who worshipped the Buddha

I will proclaim him,
listen to my words.
For twenty-one thousand eons,

For twenty-one eons, the lord of gods,

It will be three hundred leagues in height,
and two hundred and fifty leagues in breadth.
With four hundred thousand doors,
and well-built archways,

adorned with a great bed.
Hundreds of thousands of koṭis
of celestial nymphs will surround him;
Skilled in dance and song,
Even when the verse was recited, he was not satisfied.
In such a fine house,
crowded with a multitude of women,
The rain of flowers will fall,
the divine red rain will always fall.
On the wall pegs, on the elephant tusks,
on the doorposts, on the architraves,
The red wheels,
will hang there for a while.
In the fine house, covered inside with leaves and bowls,
Having spread it out and covered it,
they will roll around there for a while.
Surrounding the dwelling,
all around for twenty leagues,
Those red lotuses,
will waft a divine fragrance.
Fifty-five times,
he will be a wheel-turning monarch;
The extensive kingdom of a minor king,
incalculable by number.
Having experienced two kinds of prosperity,
without decline or calamity,
At the end of his success,
he will attain Nibbāna.’
Indeed, the Buddha was well seen by me,
the trade was well employed;
Having worshipped the three lotuses,
I experienced the three kinds of success.
Today, having attained the Dhamma,
completely liberated in every way,
A lovely red-flowering bush,
he will hold on his head.
As I was telling of my deed,
of the Teacher Padumuttara,
To a hundred thousand beings
there was a penetration of the Dhamma.
